player_decision.reason: Q5s is a playable, suited queen in late position — raise to 20 (minimum) to try to steal the blinds and take initiative while risking little.

With 9d 8c in a 3-handed pot, facing a 20 bet after blinds (pot 35), calling keeps you in with a marginal but playable hand and a decent stack depth (95). Raising would be aggressive with a weak hand, and folding is too tight here. See a flop and reassess.
We’re closing the action getting 5:1 in the big blind; T7o is a standard defend multiway. Too weak to squeeze, good price to see a flop.

On a dry flop (5h 7c 2s) with 9d8c you have a 4-out straight draw and are currently in a multiway pot. There’s no strong reason to fear immediate aggression, so checking/calling to see turn and river lets you realize equity and control pot size rather than risking a big pot with a marginal hand.
Check to the preflop raiser with top pair on a dry board; keep pot manageable and allow them to c-bet, then decide between call/raise based on sizing and reactions.

I have top pair (5) with a good kicker (Q) on a dry flop (5h 7c 2s). Bet ~half the pot for value and protection — extracts value from worse hands and denies free cards while keeping the pot controlled.

With 9d8c on a 5h 7c 2s flop, you have a 4-out gutshot to a straight (~16.5% by river) and are facing a 30 bet in a 3-way pot. The pot is ~90; calling 30 leaves you with ~50 and an expected value below folding. The pot odds (≈25%) don’t justify calling or raising here, so folding preserves equity and is +EV in this spot.

We have middle pair on a dry board and effective SPR is under 1 (pot 90, villain 50 behind). Calling commits us anyway and gives overcards a free turn; shoving now maximizes fold equity and denies equity to his c-bet bluffs.

Facing an all‑in, my Q5 (paired 5 on flop) is likely behind many hands Alice would shove (overpairs, sets) and only has ~20% equity vs those ranges. Calling 50 to win ~220 requires ~22.7% equity, so this is a +EV fold to preserve my tournament life.
